channel.title: LED strobe light
channel.description:
In season 8 episode 4 (Risky Business) from House M.D., Dr. House claims he built a hand held (strobe light) device with hundreds of LED lights with which he causes a fellow doctor to vomit violently.
He mentions that the LED's are flashing at random intervals and with random wavelengths, and this is what causes people being flashed to lose balance and vomit.
Does any one know what materials I would need to build one of these?

He mentions that the led lights are flashing at random intervals and with random wavelengths, and this is what causes people being flashed to lose balance and vomit.

Does any one know what materials I would need to build one of these?[/u][/quote]

hello friend which is the best source to get LED strobe lights at affordable prices?Waiting for reply thanks in advance:)

Read full topic

item.title: LED strobe light
item.dc:creator: @Smokey2 Smokey_
item.description:
@Smokey2 wrote:

You don’t necessarily need to change wavelengths, the effect is cause by your eyes not being able to adjust to the light before another comes on. If it’s between 1 - 20 Hz, it will be just as effective. I know the code for this would be simple, but you would need a developers board or something of the sort. I’m not into electronics much so I don’t know much about it, although I’ve seen components at radio shack that would suit this just fine.

Read full topic

item.title: LED strobe light

item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LED_Incapacitator

Some test subjects have been completely unaffected by the light, and although the manufacture makes wide and un-based claims about the product's effectiveness, the CEO of Intelligent Optics, the producer of the device, has actually commented "I don’t think we've had anyone actually be sick

Read full topic

item.title: LED strobe light
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

LED Incapacitator

The Light Emitting Diode (LED) Incapacitator is a weapon designed like a flashlight. It emits an extremely bright, rapid, and well-focused series of 'differently-colored random pulses.' Before the human eyes can focus in on one frequency, another frequency comes on, causing intracranial pressure, which results in cluster headaches, nausea, vomiting, disorientation, irritability, and visual impairment to the target (opponent). The non-lethal weapon is intended as a means of protection by law enfor...

Read full topic

item.title: LED strobe light
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Flicker vertigo

Flicker vertigo, sometimes called the Bucha effect, is "an imbalance in brain-cell activity caused by exposure to low-frequency flickering (or flashing) of a relatively bright light." It is a disorientation-, vertigo-, and nausea-inducing effect of a strobe light flashing at 1 Hz to 20 Hz, approximately the frequency of human brainwaves. The effects are similar to seizures caused by epilepsy (in particular photosensitive epilepsy), but are not restricted to people with histories of epile This phe...

Apparently, all it has to do is flash at 1 to 20Hz.

Read full topic

item.title: LED strobe light
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

zyle1992:

Changing the wave length would be harder to do; but just having randomly flashing LEDs isn’t hard. You can either have it “random” In the sense that the LED being flashed is random, or you can have enough LEDs, light one after another in a predetermined “random” manner, with different timers, so that it’s being perceived as random.

Well when I say random, I mean all the LEDs at the same time.

For example:

In the first cycle, they all light up at the same time at 100% for 1 second then they all turn off
In the next cycle (right after they turn off), they all light up at the same time with a random percentage of power.
etc.

Read full topic
